What's the best way to paint a large room?

Here’s a step-by-step approach to get a smooth, even finish when painting a large room:

1. Plan & buy materials  
   • Measure the room: add up the perimeter × height for wall area (and ceiling if you’re painting it).  
   • Calculate paint needed: most paints cover 350–400 sq ft per gallon. Allow for two coats (and primer, if using).  
   • Choose finish (e.g. eggshell or satin for walls, flat for ceilings) and quality paint.  
   • Gather tools:  
     – Paint (plus primer if covering dark or stained walls)  
     – Roller frames, roller covers (11–18 mm nap for smooth walls; 18–25 mm for light texture)  
     – Extension pole for rollers  
     – 2–3″ angled sash brush for cutting in  
     – Paint tray and liners  
     – Drop cloths or plastic sheeting  
     – Painter’s tape (low-tack)  
     – Spackle or filler, putty knife  
     – Sandpaper (120–220 grit)  
     – Ladder or step stool  
     – Rags, bucket of clean water (for latex paint)  
     – Mild detergent or TSP substitute (for cleaning walls)

2. Prep the room  
   • Remove or cover furniture and fixtures; protect floors with drop cloths.  
   • Take down switch plates, outlet covers, curtain rods, light-fixture covers.  
   • Fill holes and cracks with spackle; let dry, then sand smooth.  
   • Wash walls lightly to remove dust or grease; allow to dry completely.  
   • Apply painter’s tape along trim, window and door edges, baseboards.

3. Prime (if needed)  
   • Use a stain-blocking primer on patched areas or if you’re making a big color change.  
   • Let primer dry fully (check manufacturer’s recommended drying time).

4. “Cut in” the edges first  
   • With your angled sash brush, paint a 2–3″ border along ceilings, corners, around windows/doors and baseboards.  
   • Work methodically, keeping a wet edge to avoid lap marks.

5. Roll on the main field  
   • Pour paint into a tray, fully load the roller, then roll off the excess.  
   • Use an extension pole to reach high areas easily and maintain an even pressure.  
   • Apply paint in a “W” or “M” pattern about 4 ft square, then fill in without lifting the roller. This ensures uniform coverage.  
   • Work quickly in sections, blending each new patch into the wet edge of the last.

6. Let first coat dry & inspect  
   • Follow paint can instructions for dry time (usually 2–4 hours for latex).  
   • Look for thin spots or roller lines; lightly sand any drips or bumps with fine-grit sandpaper.

7. Apply the second coat  
   • Repeat cutting in and rolling just as you did the first time. Two coats will give the richest, most durable finish.

8. Remove tape & clean up  
   • Peel painter’s tape off while paint is still slightly tacky to avoid peeling dried paint.  
   • Wash brushes and rollers with warm, soapy water (for latex paint) or the appropriate solvent for oil-based paints.  
   • Reinstall hardware, switch plates, curtains, and furniture once everything is fully dry (typically 24 hours).

9. Tips for the best results  
   • Work top to bottom: paint the ceiling first (if that’s part of your plan), then walls, then trim.  
   • Keep the room well-ventilated for faster drying and to reduce fumes.  
   • Maintain a consistent light source (natural or a bright work light) so you can see missed spots and lap marks.  
   • Don’t skimp on quality rollers and brushes—they leave fewer fibers behind and give a smoother finish.

With good prep, the right tools and a systematic approach, you’ll cover your entire room evenly and efficiently—no patchy walls or brush strokes in sight!

How do I prevent paint from drying out in the can?

Here are some simple steps to keep leftover paint fresh in the can:

1. Clean the rim and lid  
   – After you’re done painting, wipe any drips or excess paint off the can’s lip and lid with a rag.  
   – A clean seal helps keep air—and skinning—out.

2. Add a barrier (water-based paint only)  
   – For latex or acrylic paint, you can pour a very thin layer of water (just a tablespoon or two) on top of the paint before sealing.  
   – The water floats on top and helps block air. Don’t overdo it—too much water can dilute the paint if it seeps in.

3. Use plastic wrap or a plastic bag  
   – Stretch a piece of cling film over the can opening before you press the lid back on.  
   – This extra gasket helps block air better than can-lid alone.

4. Seal the lid tightly  
   – Place the lid on straight and tap it down gently with a rubber mallet or the handle of a screwdriver.  
   – Avoid bending the lid’s flange or you’ll compromise the seal.

5. Store the can upside down  
   – Turning the can upside down (lid on the floor) creates an airtight seal around the rim.  
   – Keep it on a stable surface where it won’t accidentally tip.

6. Keep in a cool, dry place  
   – Avoid direct sunlight, high heat or freezing temperatures.  
   – A basement, garage shelf or utility closet is ideal—just don’t let it freeze.

7. Consider a smaller container  
   – If you only have a little paint left, transfer it to a clean, airtight jar or plastic tub sized for the amount you have.  
   – Less air space helps keep paint from skinning over.

8. Use a paint conditioner or retarder  
   – For longer open-time (especially in hot/dry climates), mix in a few drops of commercial paint conditioner designed for your paint type.  

By following these steps you’ll minimise air exposure and temperature shocks—and your paint will stay smooth and usable for your next touch-up.

How do I paint behind a refrigerator?

Here’s a safe, step-by-step way to get the wall (and baseboard, if you wish) behind your refrigerator freshly painted:

1. Prepare the fridge  
   • Empty or remove as many items as you can—especially anything on top or in the door bins.  
   • Unplug the appliance or switch it off at its outlet or breaker.  
   • If you have a water-line (ice maker, water dispenser), turn off the shut-off valve and disconnect the hose.  

2. Move the refrigerator  
   • Slide it straight out from the wall.  If it’s heavy, enlist a friend or use furniture sliders under the feet.  
   • Lay down a drop cloth or rosin paper on the floor behind where the fridge sits to protect your flooring.  

3. Prep the wall and trim  
   • Clean the wall of dust, grease or any spills—use a mild detergent or TSP substitute and a sponge. Let it fully dry.  
   • Fill any nail holes or cracks with spackling compound; once dry, sand lightly.  
   • Remove outlet/switch cover plates (turn power back off first!)  
   • Use painter’s tape to mask any areas you don’t want painted (adjacent cabinets, baseboard, floor trim).  

4. Prime (if needed)  
   • If your wall has stains or bare drywall patches, apply a coat of primer and let it dry per the manufacturer’s instructions.  

5. Paint  
   • “Cut in” the edges with a 2–3″ angled sash brush along the ceiling line, corners and around outlets.  
   • Use a small roller (6″–9″ mini roller is very handy in a tight spot) to fill in the field. Two light coats usually give the best coverage—allow proper drying time between coats.  

6. Re-install and clean up  
   • Remove painter’s tape before the last coat is fully cured (this helps prevent peeling).  
   • Re-attach outlet covers once the paint is dry.  
   • Carefully slide the refrigerator back into place—check that it’s level and at least a half-inch from the wall for air circulation.  
   • Reconnect the water line, plug it back in, and restock your fridge.  

Tips  
• If you really can’t pull the fridge completely forward, consider a long-handled mini-roller or an extension paint brush—but results won’t be as even as when it’s fully accessible.  
• Work in mild temperatures and good ventilation to help paint dry properly.  
• Always keep a flashlight handy to spot any unpainted areas behind the appliance.

What's the best way to paint a ceiling without roller marks?

Here’s a step-by-step approach to get a smooth, mark-free ceiling finish:

1. Prepare the room and surface  
   • Move furniture out or to the room’s center and cover with dust sheets.  
   • Remove or mask off light fixtures, vents and trim with painter’s tape.  
   • Fill any holes or cracks with a suitable filler, sand smooth and dust off.

2. Choose the right products and tools  
   • Paint: use a quality ceiling or flat interior paint (often paint+primer in one). Flat finishes hide imperfections best.  
   • Roller frame & pole: lightweight frame with extension pole to keep your arm straight up.  
   • Roller cover: low‐nap (¼" to ½") microfiber or woven roller for minimal stipple. On very smooth ceilings you can go as low as 3⁄16".  
   • Cutting-in brush: synthetic bristle angled sash brush, about 2″–2½″ wide.  
   • Optional: paint pan, liners, stir stick, drop cloths.

3. Cut in the perimeter first  
   • Working in 1½–2 m sections, “cut in” around walls, corners and fixtures with your angled brush.  
   • Keep a wet edge to avoid lap marks—don’t let the cut-in dry before you roll adjacent areas.

4. Roll using the “Wet-Edge W” technique  
   • Load your roller lightly—dip, then roll off excess in the pan’s grid. Overloaded rollers drip and leave thick edges.  
   • Start at one corner; paint a loose “W” or “M” shape about 1 m² in area.  
   • Without reloading, fill in the shape with parallel strokes, then finish with a light, un-reloaded pass in one direction (usually toward the nearest wall) to even out the paint.  
   • Always overlap your previous section by a few inches while the paint is still wet to avoid lap lines.

5. Maintain consistent pressure and pace  
   • Don’t press hard. Let the roller’s nap do the work. Light, even pressure gives the most uniform texture.  
   • Work at a steady pace so the paint doesn’t start to dry before you blend edges.

6. Inspect and touch up immediately  
   • As you go, glance back under good light (a bright work lamp at an angle reveals marks).  
   • While still wet, smooth out any ridges or thick spots with a light re-roll.

7. Apply a second coat  
   • After the first coat is fully dry (check paint can for drying times), repeat the same method. Two thin coats look better and are less prone to roller marks than one heavy coat.

Tips & tricks  
   • Temperature/humidity: paint in moderate conditions (10–25 °C, not too humid).  
   • Clean roller covers and brushes immediately after use; a clogged cover can leave streaks next time.  
   • For perfectly smooth ceilings, consider an airless sprayer—spraying takes practice but leaves virtually no texture.  

Following these steps—good prep, the right roller, controlled paint load and the wet-edge “W” rolling method—will give you a smooth, professional-looking ceiling free of roller marks.

How do I paint over stained wood trim?

Here’s a reliable step-by-step method for painting over stained wood trim. You’ll need basic tools and supplies you can find at most hardware stores.

1. Gather tools and materials  
   • Drop cloths or old sheets  
   • Painter’s tape  
   • Cleaning solution (TSP substitute or mild detergent)  
   • Fine- to medium-grit sandpaper (120–150 grit) and extra-fine (220 grit)  
   • Sanding block or hand sander  
   • Vacuum or soft brush and tack cloths  
   • Wood filler (for nail holes or gaps) and putty knife  
   • Paintable acrylic latex caulk (for trim joints)  
   • Stain-blocking primer (oil-based or shellac-based)  
   • High-quality trim paint (acrylic latex enamel or water-based alkyd recommended)  
   • Angled sash brush (2" or 2½") and small foam or microfiber roller (optional)  
   • Stir sticks, paint tray, gloves and safety glasses  

2. Prep the area  
   a. Remove any switch-plate covers and outlet plates.  
   b. Lay down drop cloths to protect the floor.  
   c. Mask off the wall or adjacent surfaces with painter’s tape.  

3. Clean the trim  
   a. Wipe the trim with a TSP substitute or mild soapy water to remove grease, dust and fingerprints.  
   b. Rinse with clean water and let fully dry.  

4. Sand the stained surface  
   a. Lightly sand with 120–150 grit just to scuff the finish—this helps primer adhere.  
   b. Fill any nail holes or gouges with wood filler, let dry, then sand smooth.  
   c. Finish with 220-grit for a uniform, smooth surface.  

5. Remove dust  
   a. Vacuum or brush off sanding dust.  
   b. Wipe with a tack cloth to pick up fine particles.  

6. Caulk gaps  
   a. Run a bead of paintable acrylic latex caulk along joints between trim and wall or between trim pieces.  
   b. Smooth with your finger or a caulking tool. Wipe away excess.  
   c. Let caulk cure per manufacturer’s instructions.  

7. Apply stain-blocking primer  
   a. Stir the primer well.  
   b. Using an angled brush, cut in at corners and edges.  
   c. Fill the flat surfaces with primer—use a small roller for wider profiles if you like.  
   d. Allow the primer to dry fully (check label for drying time).  
   e. Lightly sand the primed surface with 220 grit, then remove dust.  

8. Paint the trim  
   a. Stir your trim paint gently—avoid whipping in bubbles.  
   b. Cut in along the inside edge with the sash brush.  
   c. Paint the face of the trim, working one section at a time. Use long, smooth brush strokes in the direction of the wood grain.  
   d. Apply a second coat after the first is dry (usually 4–6 hours). Lightly sand between coats for an ultra-smooth finish.  

9. Clean up  
   a. Remove painter’s tape before the final coat fully cures to avoid peeling.  
   b. Reinstall hardware and switch plates.  
   c. Clean brushes and rollers per paint manufacturer’s instructions.  

Tips  
• Choose a paint finish that’s easy to clean—semi-gloss or satin are popular for trim.  
• Ensure good ventilation while priming and painting.  
• Work in moderate temperature (ideally 50–85°F) and low humidity for best drying.  

Following these steps will give you a durable, professional‐looking finish over stained wood trim. Good luck with your project!

How do I paint over varnished wood?

Here’s a reliable step-by-step method for painting over varnished wood:

1. Remove hardware and protect surroundings  
   • Take off knobs, hinges or any removable fittings.  
   • Lay down drop-cloths or masking paper to catch dust and drips.  

2. Clean the surface  
   • Wipe the wood with a mild detergent solution (e.g. warm water plus a few drops of dish soap).  
   • Rinse with clean water and allow to dry completely.  

3. Sand to degloss and key the surface  
   • Use 120- to 150-grit sandpaper (or a sanding block) to dull the varnish.  
   • Lightly sand in the direction of the grain—your goal is to scuff up the finish, not remove it completely.  
   • Remove all sanding dust with a vacuum or soft brush, then wipe with a tack cloth.

4. Fill any cracks or holes (if needed)  
   • Use a wood-filler that’s compatible with your primer/paint system.  
   • Apply with a putty knife, let dry, then sand smooth.

5. Prime with a bonding or stain-blocking primer  
   • Choose an oil-based or high-adhesion acrylic primer designed for glossy surfaces.  
   • Apply one even coat, brushing into corners and working out any drips.  
   • Let the primer dry fully (follow manufacturer’s dry-time instructions).

6. Lightly sand the primed surface  
   • Use 220-grit sandpaper to knock down any raised grain or tiny imperfections.  
   • Wipe off dust with a clean, dry cloth.

7. Apply your topcoat  
   • Select an interior or exterior wood paint (acrylic or alkyd) depending on the project.  
   • Apply at least two coats, allowing recommended drying time between coats.  
   • For best results, sand very lightly (320-grit) between coats and remove dust.

8. Re-install hardware and enjoy  
   • Once the paint is fully cured, reattach hinges and knobs.  
   • Protect the finish by waiting a few days before heavy use.

Alternative shortcut (when sanding isn’t practical):  
   • Use a high-quality liquid deglosser (sometimes called “liquid sandpaper”) to etch the varnish.  
   • After wiping on and removing the deglosser per instructions, proceed directly to priming.

Tips:  
   • Always work in a well-ventilated area.  
   • Match paint sheen to the room’s needs—satin or semi-gloss for easy cleaning.  
   • Follow all manufacturer instructions on primer and paint cans.

What's the most durable paint tray?

Here are the key factors that determine a paint tray’s durability—and a few of the toughest trays on the market:

1. Tray Material  
   • Stainless-steel or powder-coated steel  
     – Virtually unbreakable, won’t crack or warp under solvent-based paints.  
     – Easy to clean and resistant to rust (especially 304-grade stainless).  
   • Heavy-duty polypropylene (HDPE)  
     – Very tough plastic that resists solvents, impact and UV.  
     – Won’t dent but can scratch if you’re not careful.

2. Reinforced Design  
   • Rolled or stiffened edges – prevent the tray from flexing or buckling under pressure.  
   • Ribbed or flanged bottom – adds strength and minimizes warping when set on uneven surfaces.  
   • Anti-slip feet or rubber base – keeps the tray stable and reduces wear on the bottom.

3. Size & Capacity  
   • Deeper “well” holds more paint, reducing spills and allowing thorough roller saturation.  
   • Larger pour spout (for steel trays) makes cleaning and refilling easier without drips.

Top Recommendations  
1. Marshalltown Stainless-Steel Roller Tray  
   – 18″ × 12″, fully welded stainless construction, rolled rim for extra strength.  
   – Perfect for oil- and solvent-based paints; years of service with minimal upkeep.  

2. Purdy Maverick Steel Roller Tray  
   – Powder-coated steel with reinforced corner gussets.  
   – Wide lip and “pour-off” corner for mess-free draining back into the can.  

3. Hyde Pro Series Polypropylene Tray  
   – Heavy-duty HDPE, solvent-resistant, won’t crack if dropped.  
   – Includes ribbed roller ramp for even loading and anti-skid feet.  

4. Wooster Sher-R‐Grip™ Lined Tray + Disposable Liners  
   – Economy HDPE tray with a built-in flex lip for easy cleaning.  
   – Add disposable liners to keep the tray surface like new and cut cleaning time.

Tips for Maximum Lifespan  
• Use disposable liners whenever possible.  
• Rinse (steel) or wipe clean (plastic) immediately after use—don’t let paint dry in the tray.  
• Store trays upside down or hanging to prevent trapped moisture and deformation.  

In general, if you’re looking for absolute longevity, go with a stainless-steel tray. If you need something lighter and still very tough, high-grade polypropylene is the next best choice.

How do I paint over lead paint safely?

Here’s a general, step-by-step approach to sealing (encapsulating) existing lead‐based paint rather than scraping or stripping it. Any time you work with lead paint you’re creating a potential health hazard, so if at any point you feel unsure, stop work and consult or hire an EPA-certified renovator in your area.  

1.  Test for lead  
    •  If you don’t already know you have lead paint, use an EPA-approved home test kit or hire a professional to confirm.  

2.  Prepare and contain the work area  
    •  Seal doors, vents and windows with 6 mil plastic sheeting and painter’s tape.  
    •  Lay down drop cloths or plastic on floors and furniture.  
    •  Turn off central air systems or seal vents to avoid spreading dust.  

3.  Protect yourself  
    •  Wear an N-100 or P-100 respirator (NIOSH-approved for lead).  
    •  Use disposable gloves (nitrile or latex) and coveralls or old clothing.  
    •  Wear goggles—do not rely on a dust mask.  

4.  Clean the surface (no dry sanding!)  
    •  Wipe down walls with a solution of trisodium phosphate (TSP) or a TSP substitute.  
    •  Work wet—keep the surface damp to minimize dust.  
    •  Rinse thoroughly and let the wall fully dry before priming.  

5.  Spot‐treat any loose or flaking paint  
    •  Gently mist any peeling areas with water.  
    •  Carefully lift flakes with a putty knife. Do not sand.  
    •  Immediately collect debris on the plastic sheeting and double-bag it for disposal.  

6.  Apply a lead‐encapsulating primer  
    •  Choose a primer specifically labeled “lead encapsulant” or “lead‐blocking.”  
    •  Follow manufacturer’s instructions for application and drying times.  
    •  Apply enough coats to completely seal the old paint—usually 2 coats.  

7.  Topcoat with quality latex or acrylic paint  
    •  Once the encapsulating primer is cured, finish with your chosen topcoat.  
    •  This provides UV protection and abrasion resistance for the seal.  

8.  Clean up and disposal  
    •  Wet-wipe all plastic sheeting, tools and work surfaces.  
    •  Collect wipes, rags, and plastic in heavy-duty bags; label as lead-paint waste if local rules require.  
    •  Check your municipality’s hazardous-waste rules for where to drop off.  

9.  Final check  
    •  Do a wet wipe or HEPA-vacuum of the area to remove any remaining dust.  
    •  Keep children and pregnant women out of the work area until everything is cleaned up.  

Important reminders:  
•  If you need to disturb more than 2 sq ft (interior) or 20 sq ft (exterior) of lead paint, U.S. federal rules generally require an EPA‐certified contractor.  
•  Always follow local regulations—some areas have tighter rules than the federal minimum.  
•  When in doubt, hire an EPA‐certified lead renovator.  

By encapsulating rather than stripping, you avoid generating hazardous lead dust. Done properly, this is one of the safest and most cost-effective ways to “paint over” lead paint.

What's the best way to paint wicker furniture?

Here’s a step-by-step method for getting a durable, attractive finish on wicker—whether it’s natural rattan or resin/poly wicker.  

1. Prepare your workspace   
 • Work outdoors or in a very well-ventilated area.  
 • Lay down a drop cloth to catch drips and protect the floor.  

2. Clean the wicker thoroughly  
 • Dust first with a soft brush or vacuum with a brush attachment.  
 • Mix warm water with a mild dish soap.  
 • Scrub gently with a soft-bristle brush or sponge, getting into all the crevices.  
 • Rinse well with clean water (a spray-bottle rinse works nicely).  
 • Let it dry completely—ideally 24 hours—before moving on.  

3. Remove loose paint and rough spots  
 • If old paint is peeling or chipping, use a small wire brush or medium-grit sandpaper (120–150 grit) to knock off all loose flakes.  
 • Lightly sand the entire surface (this gives new primer and paint something to “grab” onto).  
 • Wipe away dust with a tack cloth or a damp microfiber towel.  

4. Mask off areas you don’t want painted  
 • Use painter’s tape to cover glides, hardware, cushions, etc.  

5. Prime the wicker  
 • Choose a primer formulated for your material:  
   – For natural wicker/rattan, use a quality oil- or water-based bonding primer.  
   – For resin/poly-wicker, choose a primer labeled for plastics or vinyl.  
 • Apply in thin, even coats, using either:  
   – Spray primer (fastest for intricate weaving)  
   – A small foam or synthetic-bristle brush  
 • Allow the primer to dry thoroughly (follow the manufacturer’s recommended dry time).  

6. Paint in thin, even coats  
 Option A: Spray paint  
   • Use a spray paint made for outdoor furniture or all-surface enamel.  
   • Hold the can about 25–30 cm from the surface.  
   • Apply multiple light coats rather than one heavy coat—this avoids drips and pooling.  

 Option B: Brush-on paint  
   • Use a high-quality exterior acrylic or alkyd enamel paint.  
   • With a small synthetic-bristle brush, work into gaps and around curves.  
   • Wipe excess paint from the brush before each pass to prevent blobs.  
   • Let each coat dry fully, then lightly sand (220 grit) before applying the next coat.  

7. Apply 2–3 coats for even coverage  
 • Allow proper flash time (check can instructions) between coats.  
 • Inspect under good light to catch any thin spots or drips.  

8. Seal (optional but recommended for outdoor furniture)  
 • Once the paint is fully cured (often 24–48 hours), brush or spray on a clear exterior polyurethane or clear acrylic sealer.  
 • This adds UV protection and helps resist scratches and mildew.  

9. Cure and reassemble  
 • Give the piece a full 48–72 hours to cure before heavy use or exposure to rain.  
 • Remove tape, reattach hardware, and put cushions back on.  

Tips & Tricks  
 • Temperature and humidity matter—ideal conditions are 15–25 °C (60–75 °F) and low humidity.  
 • Protect your lungs—wear a mask rated for paint fumes and primer vapors.  
 • Work in sections—finish the back or underside first in case of drips.  

Following these steps will help you achieve a smooth, long-lasting finish on your wicker furniture. Enjoy your refreshed piece!

What's the best way to paint a narrow hallway?

Here’s a step-by-step approach to painting a narrow hallway cleanly and efficiently:

1. Preparation  
   • Clear the space – remove pictures, furniture or cover with drop cloths.  
   • Protect floors and trim – lay down tarp or plastic sheeting and use painter’s tape along skirting boards, door frames and light switches.  
   • Patch and sand – fill nail holes or cracks with filler, let dry, then lightly sand smooth. Wipe walls with a damp cloth to remove dust.

2. Choose the right paint and tools  
   • Paint finish – an eggshell or satin finish cleans easily and reflects a bit of light to visually widen the hallway.  
   • Light colors – soft neutrals, pastels or off-whites make narrow spaces feel larger and brighter.  
   • Roller size – use a 4–6 inch mini roller with a medium-nap cover (⅜″–½″ nap) for better maneuverability in tight spaces.  
   • Angled sash brush (2–2½″) – ideal for cutting in around trim, corners and light fixtures.  
   • Extension pole – helps reach higher walls and ceilings without a ladder.

3. Cutting in  
   • Start with edges – use your angled brush to “cut in” a 2–3 inch border along the ceiling line, corners and around door frames.  
   • Work in 4–5 foot sections to keep a wet edge and minimize visible overlaps.

4. Rolling the walls  
   • Load roller sparingly – overload can drip in a narrow space. Roll off excess paint on the tray’s slope.  
   • Top to bottom – roll from ceiling line down to the top of the cut-in band, then finish the strip down to the floor in smooth ‘W’ or ‘M’ strokes.  
   • Blend each section – before the paint skins over, lightly roll the junction between the fresh paint and the cut-in area to even out texture.

5. Second coat  
   • Dry time – allow the first coat to dry fully (check your paint can for recommended time).  
   • Inspect light-facing walls – if the previous coat looks uneven, apply a second coat using the same technique.

6. Ceilings and trim (if needed)  
   • Ceilings first – if you’re also painting the ceiling, do it before the walls to avoid splatter. Use a roller with a ¾″ nap.  
   • Trim last – finish baseboards, door frames and moldings with a semi-gloss or gloss paint for durability; use a small sash brush for crisp lines.

7. Cleanup and inspection  
   • Remove tape – pull away painter’s tape at a 45° angle while paint is still slightly tacky to get clean edges.  
   • Touch-ups – after everything’s dry, check for minor drips or thin spots and gently fix with a small brush.  
   • Ventilate – keep doors or windows open to speed drying and dissipate fumes.

Bonus tips  
   – Good lighting: place a work light or bulb at one end to spot uneven coverage.  
   – Step ladder: in very narrow halls you can often lean a drywall stilts or a narrow stepladder against one wall for easy access without blocking too much space.  
   – Ventilation: an open window or small fan helps paint cure faster and improves comfort.

With careful prep, the right tools and light-reflecting colors, your narrow hallway will look bright, fresh and more spacious. Good luck with your project!

How can I avoid cleaning paint trays between uses?

Here are a few easy ways to skip scrubbing your metal or plastic paint tray between coats or between days of work:

1. Use disposable tray-liners  
   • Buy purpose-made plastic or foil liners that simply snap into your tray.  
   • When you’ve finished, peel out the liner and toss it—tray stays clean.  
   • Liners come in packs of 5–10 and fit standard 9×14″ trays.

2. Line your tray with aluminium foil  
   • Tear off a piece of heavy-duty foil, press it firmly into the tray’s corners and ridges.  
   • Paint as normal; then remove and discard the foil when you’re done.

3. Cover and store between sessions  
   • If you’re sticking with the same paint colour, press cling film (or a large freezer bag) tightly over the paint surface and around the tray edges.  
   • Remove the plastic the next day and paint on—no cleaning required.  
   • This only works if the paint doesn’t change colour and you work again within a day or two.

4. Switch to a silicone tray  
   • Silicone paint trays let you peel off fully cured paint in one rubbery sheet—tray is clean underneath.  
   • They’re more expensive up front but reusable dozens of times without washing.

5. Use a 5-gallon bucket and grid (optional)  
   • Pour your paint into a bucket, clip in a paint-grid for loading rollers, and keep the bucket covered between breaks.  
   • The paint stays fresh, and you never have to clean a flat tray again.

Pick the option that best suits your workflow and budget. Disposable liners or foil are cheapest; silicone trays give you a long-term “no-wash” solution; and buckets with grids are great for large jobs.

What's the best way to paint kitchen cabinets for durability?

Here’s a tried-and-true approach to get a hard-wearing, professional-looking finish on kitchen cabinets:

1. Remove and label  
  • Take off all doors, drawers and hardware (hinges, knobs, pulls).  
  • Label doors/drawers and corresponding cabinet openings so reassembly is foolproof.

2. Clean thoroughly  
  • Degrease with a trisodium phosphate (TSP) substitute or a dedicated kitchen cleaner.  
  • Wipe off every trace of grease, grime and dust.  
  • Allow to dry completely.

3. Sand or scuff  
  • Lightly sand all surfaces with 120–150 grit paper (a sanding block or detail sander works best).  
  • Your goal is to remove the old gloss and give the primer something to “bite” into.  
  • Wipe down with a tack cloth or microfiber to remove sanding dust.

4. Fill and spot-prime  
  • Fill any nail/screw holes or dents with a stain-blocking, paintable wood filler.  
  • Sand smooth once dry, and wipe clean.  
  • Spot-prime bare wood or filler spots with an adhesion primer.

5. Prime all surfaces  
  • Use a high-adhesion, stain-blocking primer formulated for cabinetry or laminate (Zava Bonding Primer or equivalent).  
  • Apply as directed—either spray, brush or fine foam roller.  
  • Let dry and lightly scuff with 220 grit if it feels “fuzzy,” then clean off the dust.

6. Topcoat with enamel paint  
  • For durability choose either:  
    – Water-borne acrylic enamel (low odor, fast-dry, easy cleanup)  
    – Oil-based or alkyd enamel (ultra-hard finish, longer cure time)  
  • Apply two thin, even coats rather than one thick coat.  
  • Brushes: use a high-quality nylon/polyester brush. Rollers: use a fine (¼") foam or microfiber roller. Spraying gives the smoothest result but requires masking.  
  • Between coats, follow the manufacturer’s dry time and lightly sand with 320–400 grit if needed.

7. Optional clear protective topcoat  
  • For extra chemical and scratch resistance, apply a water-based polyurethane or conversion varnish (catalyzed lacquer) over the enamel.  
  • This step is especially recommended for busy kitchens.

8. Curing and reassembly  
  • Even if the paint feels dry, full curing can take 5–7 days—avoid hanging heavy towels or scrubbing during this period.  
  • Reattach hardware and doors carefully, and adjust hinges if needed for perfect alignment.

Tips for success  
  • Work in a dust-free, well-ventilated space.  
  • Keep temperatures within the paint’s recommended range (usually 50–85°F / 10–30°C).  
  • Maintain a wet-edge when rolling or brushing to avoid lap marks.  
  • Label your tools (e.g. “Primer only”) to avoid cross-contamination.  

Following these steps will give you a smooth, durable finish that stands up to daily wear in the kitchen. Good luck with your project!

How do I prevent lap marks when painting ceilings?

Here are some tried-and-true tips for avoiding lap marks when painting a ceiling:

1. Choose the right paint and tools  
   • Use a quality ceiling paint or flat latex formulated for low sheen and good hide.  
   • Pick a roller cover with the proper nap: 9–12 mm (⅜"–½") nap is ideal for most ceilings to hold enough paint without overloading.  
   • Use an extension pole so you can keep a steady arm position and consistent pressure across the whole area.

2. Prepare and prime the surface  
   • Clean the ceiling of dust, cobwebs and any loose paint.  
   • Repair cracks or holes with spackling compound, then sand smooth.  
   • If the ceiling is new drywall or stained, apply a ready-mixed drywall primer or stain-blocking primer. A consistent base helps the topcoat flow more evenly.

3. Work methodically and keep a wet edge  
   • Divide the ceiling into manageable sections—about 1.2–1.5 m (4–5 ft) wide—marking them in your mind or lightly with chalk.  
   • Load your roller and start at one corner. Roll a “W” or “M” shape across the first section, then fill in without lifting the roller.  
   • Always finish each section back to its starting point before the paint skins over. This “wet edge” prevents a second pass from drying before you overlap it.

4. Maintain even pressure and overlap correctly  
   • Don’t press too hard—let the roller’s nap do the work.  
   • Overlap each pass by about 10–15 cm (4–6 in). Too little overlap leaves gaps; too much can lead to heavy spots that lap.  
   • Reload the roller frequently so you’re not patching dry spots or rolling out with a nearly empty cover.

5. Control your environment  
   • Paint when temperatures are between 10–25 °C (50–77 °F) and humidity is moderate.  
   • Good ventilation speeds drying but avoid strong drafts that could cause the edges to set up unevenly.  
   • If you need a second coat, wait until the first coat is fully dry (check the manufacturer’s instructions—often 4–6 hours) and repeat the same wet-edge technique.

6. Final pass for a uniform finish  
   • Once the first coat is dry, do one more “light” finish roll: back-roll each section with a roller that has a thin film of paint, going in one direction only.  
   • This evens out any slight overlaps or texture differences.

Following these steps—good prep, the right roller, consistent loading, and maintaining a wet edge—will help you achieve a smooth, uniform ceiling without lap marks. Good luck with your project!

Which exterior paint is best for preventing water damage?

For most exterior surfaces, the single biggest factor in keeping water out is using a high-quality, water-resistant coating system rather than a bargain-basement paint. In practice that means:

1. 100% acrylic latex exterior paint with waterproofing additives  
   • Excellent adhesion, flexibility and UV resistance  
   • Microporous finish lets trapped moisture escape without letting new moisture in  
   • Widely available under brands such as Dulux Weathershield, Benjamin Moore Aura Exterior, Sherwin-Williams Duration  

2. Elastomeric or masonry coatings (for stucco, concrete or brick)  
   • Very high build (150–250 µm per coat) bridges hairline cracks and withstands substrate movement  
   • Forms a thick, rubber-like membrane that sheds rainwater  
   • Look for products labeled “elastomeric exterior coating” or “masonry waterproofing paint”  

3. Silicone-modified or siloxane-based paints (for highly porous masonry)  
   • Silane/siloxane chemistry penetrates deeply and repels water while still allowing vapor exchange  
   • Ideal for stone, blockwork, terracotta or any very absorbent substrate  

4. Epoxy primers or water-based epoxy topcoats (for metal, steel or high-traffic areas)  
   • Extremely hard, chemical- and moisture-resistant film  
   • Usually overcoated with a polyurethane or acrylic topcoat for UV resistance  

Key tips no matter which system you choose:  
 • Thorough surface preparation (clean, dry, free of loose paint or efflorescence)  
 • Crack-filling and joint caulking with a compatible exterior sealant  
 • Always use a quality primer suited to your substrate before topcoating  
 • Follow manufacturers’ recommendations on dry film thickness and recoat windows  

If you tell us what you’re painting (wood siding, brick, stucco, metal, etc.), we can narrow it down to a specific product that will give you the best long-term protection against water damage.

How do I paint wood siding that's never been painted?

Here’s a step-by-step guide to painting bare wood siding. Adjust products and timing to your local climate and the manufacturer’s instructions:

1. Gather tools & materials  
   • Exterior-grade cleaner or trisodium phosphate (TSP) substitute  
   • Stiff-bristle brush, garden hose or pressure washer (low‐pressure setting)  
   • Exterior wood filler or caulking (paintable, UV-resistant)  
   • Sandpaper (80‐ to 120-grit) and sanding block or pole sander  
   • Exterior primer (alkyd or 100% acrylic stain-blocking primer)  
   • Exterior paint (100% acrylic latex or premium alkyd)  
   • Brushes, rollers with a ¾"–1" nap, or paint sprayer  
   • Drop cloths, masking tape, safety glasses, gloves, dust mask or respirator  

2. Inspect & repair  
   • Check for rotten, loose or splitting boards. Repair or replace damaged sections.  
   • Fill nail or screw holes, cracks and gaps with exterior wood filler or paintable caulk.  

3. Clean the siding  
   • Remove dirt, mildew and chalk with an appropriate cleaner (TSP substitute or a mildew cleaner).  
   • Scrub with a stiff brush, then rinse thoroughly. Let the siding dry completely (24–48 hours).  

4. Sand the surface  
   • Lightly sand to remove raised grain and smooth wood filler spots.  
   • Wipe away all dust with a tack cloth or a damp rag.  

5. Prime the bare wood  
   • Apply a coat of exterior primer to all bare wood and repaired areas.  
   • Use a brush or roller, working top to bottom, maintaining a wet edge.  
   • Allow primer to dry per label instructions (often 2–4 hours).  

6. Apply the paint  
   • Stir paint thoroughly.  
   • Using brush, roller or sprayer, apply the first coat top to bottom. Overlap strokes for even coverage.  
   • Let the first coat dry fully (check can for drying time).  
   • Apply a second coat in the same manner for durability and uniform color.  

7. Clean up & inspect  
   • Remove tape while paint is still tacky.  
   • Clean brushes and rollers with water (latex paint) or mineral spirits (alkyd paint).  
   • Inspect for thin spots or drips; touch up as needed once paint is fully dry.  

8. Best practices & tips  
   • Paint when temperatures are between 50°F–85°F and humidity is below 85%.  
   • Avoid painting in direct sun or if rain is expected within 24 hours.  
   • Keep a wet edge and work in manageable sections to prevent lap marks.  
   • Use high-quality exterior paints and primers for longer life and better UV resistance.  

Following these steps will give your new wood siding a protective, attractive finish that lasts.

What paint finish is best for high-traffic areas?

For areas that get a lot of wear — hallways, family rooms, children’s bedrooms, mudrooms — you’ll want a paint with good scuff resistance and that can be wiped clean repeatedly. In most cases a satin or semi-gloss acrylic latex finish is your best choice.  

Key points:  
• Satin (also called low-sheen)  
  – Durable and scrubbable without the high shine of semi-gloss  
  – Hides small wall imperfections better than glossier finishes  
  – Good general-purpose choice for living areas and hallways  

• Semi-gloss  
  – Very durable and easy to clean  
  – Reflects more light, so scratches and uneven patching can be more visible  
  – Ideal for bathrooms, kitchens, mudrooms or any space that needs frequent washing  

Tips for best results:  
1. Use a quality primer suitable for your substrate (drywall, plaster, previously painted walls).  
2. Choose a 100% acrylic or acrylic-latex formula for maximum adhesion and flexibility.  
3. Allow adequate cure time (often 7–14 days) before heavy cleaning.  
4. Clean gently with a soft cloth or sponge and a mild detergent; avoid abrasive pads.  

If you’re undecided, we recommend Zava’s “Durable Satin Emulsion” for most high-traffic living spaces, and our “High-Traffic Semi-Gloss” for spots that need extra washability.
